That said, this place is great and in a cool location in the heart of Squirrel Hill N.

That one star was because Yelp has a compulsion of one star. Would never go back and never recommend. The food is decent but the attitude of the servers isn't. Visited with couple of friends but it was nothing short of an embarrassment. Had to ask multiple time for things and I guess asking for water was also too much. Server haggled over tip like others mentioned. Would rather walk over to the other Thai place across the street instead.

Nice tapa menu with well prepared Thai food.  Great selection of noodle dishes and curries.  The prices are fairly reasonable for what you are getting.  It won't break the bank but you won't be getting much change from a $20 either.

My complaint isn't really a complaint.  The service here is almost too good.  Like take a sip of your water and it is refilled within a minute good.  Look like your meal is done and someone is there to grab the plate.  It's just a bit much and if you're trying to have a conversation I find it distracting.  I'm just not used to that type of service either so it could "just be me".  

Located on busy Murray Avenue in Squirrel Hill Silk Elephant is a good choice amongst the many options for Thai cuisine in the area.  It's a small place but does have a nice little bar area, seating that faces Murray Avenue (for people watching) and a dining area if you want a more date-like atmosphere.
Look forward to the silk elephant every time. The atmosphere in the bar area is wonderful though the actual restaurant is a bit small. Lamb curry is by far the best.
Delivery took two hours without any notification from the restaurant. The food tastes very bad and it's not hot when it arrives.

Have always enjoyed the food here and brought an out of town guest for a special dinner. Was very disappointed. The waitress spoke such poor English that we couldn't  communicate to ask about how dishes were prepared. There was an unfamiliar fish on the special menu she was unable to describe at all, so I didn't get it. The lamb tapas I had loved on a previous visit was cut way too thin, was well done and very spicy sauce, like an 8, when I had ordered medium and 0 spicy. Sent it back. She brought it back less spicy but didn't get the part about the doneness and the same well done meat was still on the plate. 

Crab cakes were very good. Seafood salad was undressed, totally bland seafood on iceberg lettuce. Pork chops were overlooked. It took forever to get the check. We saw our waitress way on the other side of the restaurant and had to ask another waitress for the check. She said manager was not in, was at the sister restaurant.

4 stars for the pumpkin curry with tofu, 3 stars overall.

The boyfriend and I eat a lot of Thai food, and we usually opt for Thai Place or Bangkok Balcony (or, recently, Kanok).  We decided to check out Silk Elephant after a rave review from a friend.

I made reservations for Friday at 8PM, which was a good call.  The restaurant was packed and we still had to wait for a table, which was slightly annoying because there really is no lobby, especially when multiple other people are waiting.

I wasn't a huge fan of the seating; I hate being too close to the table next to me. But once we sat down, the night started improving.  Our drink orders were taken and filled quickly. We ordered the fresh rolls and they came out almost immediately, which shows how popular they are.  The peanut sauce for the rolls was delicious.

I ordered the pumpkin curry with tofu (on special) and he ordered the pad thai with tofu.  I liked the 1-10 spice scale and felt the dishes were seasoned correctly.  My only slight issue with the dish was that the tofu was grilled well done (it's possible, believe me!), which upset the balance of the soft pumpkin and curry.  

The portions were perfect for the price.  I would return and try some of the other tapas, but probably on a quieter night.

Some of the most amazing Thai food I've had!
Went for their lunch special?, which is a combination of appetizer and entree.
While the food itself was very tasty, it wasn't spicy as they claimed.
There service is impeccable and the ambience is excellent!

I really like this place for lunch. They have a much smaller menu, but for $8.5, you get a salad, spring roll, soup and entree. I absolutely love their thai noodle curry which has everything I like put in a nice hot curry (steamed noodles, cooked veggies, fresh veggies, with crispy noodles on top). They are open till 3 pm unlike other lunch places. This helps me grab late lunches that are difficult to get on Craig St. The ambience is great and is usually pretty quiet in the afternoons.

I wish the waitresses are nicer to me considering how often I go to this place. Some of them rarely smile and are super curt.

My wife and I went there for dinner on a Tuesday evening, and the place was empty (although I guess that's normal for a weeknight). The service and decore was OK- not the greatest place or as nice as I expected from their website, and our waitress was prompt but didn't refill our drinks. 
I had their shrimp pad thai, which was one of the better pad thais I've had in Pittsburgh. There was enough to take home for lunch, so the price wasn't too bad since it was a decent portion. My wife had the steamy mussels, which were good, but she got sick on them later which was bad. 
The menu is expansive with lots of tapas available, and while I didn't try anything else, the food I saw at the table nearby looked good.
I'm giving this restaurant the benefit of the doubt that it is usually better- everyone I talked to raved about it before we went. I would go there again if I was in the area and wanted Thai food, but I wouldn't go out of my way to stop there.

I tried the curry fried chicken and I was not disappointed.  The portion was huge and the flavor was out of this world.  We went to celebrate my brother's birthday, and they were most accommodating for our large party.  They also brought these delicious coconut rice bites that were phenomenal.  I would recommend this place to anyone.

A happening little date place we found ourselves in on a Friday night.  Hearing the characteristic Thai accent was promising that the food would be just as authentic.

Taro spring rolls, curry puffs, chicken wrapped in pandanus leaf all tasty.

Skip the mussels siam (rubbery) and the thai shrimp and pork toast (just a piece of deep fried bread).

Have some pretty unique cocktails---cucumber martini?!  tastes exactly like what's in it.

While the tapas can be a hit or miss, they are so reasonably priced that I'm sure we'll be back to try more!

3.5 stars.

Solid Thai place.

The environment is nice and the place has good business, so that's fun. The food is alright---can be hit or miss depending on who's cooking though. I've had from delicious fried spring rolls and savory and juicy noodles to almost rubber pad Thai and paper rolls.

The spicy meter is nice to climb up, and flavor is generally authentic. Would definitely like to see more consistency, but the food is still nice.

One of the better Thai restaurants in Pittsburgh, Silk Elephant has affordable classic lunches and a wonderful dinner menu that will temporarily paralyze anyone with indecision.  It's hard to decide between the small plates and the entrees, the obscure authentic dishes and the western favorites.

In addition to being tasty, dishes are colorful and aromatic, as the kitchen strives to present a total culinary experience.

I'd suggest going for lunch if you want a standard like rice noodles or curry, but if you're feeling adventurous, try some of the smaller sized options on the dinner menu that you won't find in your average American Thai place.

I took my adorable wife here on a tapas date before a late showing at the Manor Theater across the street. 

We had some strong cocktails, including a delicious ginger cooler with so much real ginger! We shared a variety of tiny plates, little spring rolls and puffs of taro. The veggie offerings were all delicious, although there were not too many to chose from. Actually, I think that is a blessing in disguise because too many choices among delicious little tapas makes for some tough decision making. 

The atmosphere was elegant, the lighting was romantic, and the staff was attentive without being intrusive. We held hands over the table, and played footsie underneath, and ambled into the warm summer night satisfied with our food & drink. 

The prices are pretentious, like the presentation, but it's difficult to say it's not justified with the atmosphere & attention to detail. It's something I need to drop cash on like, once a year.

To be honest, the food here is mediocre. I have been a regular customer at silk elephant because of the good price and service. That was, before my worst dining experience ever. I went for an early dinner with two of my friends. The restaurant had three occupied tables other than ours and the waitresses were not busy at all. However, the waitress did not even care to sit us. When we were finally seated, she took more than ten minutes to bring the menu, and more than an hour to bring the food. We were sitting close by to where the chef puts the food for the waitresses to deliver, and we knew that the food that came out was ours. I had to tell the waitress myself more than once before she brought our food. Moreover, she seemed to love slamming silverware and water glasses on the table. Maybe it was her own performance, but I personally thought she was rude. While I was still eating my food, she tried to take it away from me as if telling me to leave. Maybe she was hungry too.  And I am not trying to be rude about her english, since I myself am not a native, but I really could not understand her. When I asked her to repeat herself, she had her second anger moment.

I felt that I was not welcome, and that I was mistreated because I seem young. I gave a small tip. When me and my friends walked out of the restaurant, the lady ran out and caught us telling us that she deserves a tip of 15~ 20%. Also, she told me and my friends never to come again. I want to thank her for her horrendous service and attitude, and that I will never go again :).
Paul was a great waiter. Food was delicious. Would definitely recommend 6 stars if possible. Highly recommend fresh rolls, lamb chops + mysterious awesome sauce.

The best Thai restaurant on Earth and Mars and a few other planets. Every item on the menu is superb. The staff is friendly and smart. Equally good for vegetarian options. I go every week here just to uplift my mood. Awesome fine dining experience. 

Try:
Basil Fried Rice
Kee Mao
Red Curry/Penang Curry

Come enjoy a delicious Asian meal in beautiful surroundings. They have a short cocktail list, a long wine list, and a menu that includes both small and large plates. We shared the corn fritters, crab crowns (Rangoon), and silk elephant rice paper crab rolls, all delicious. For dinner we ordered basil duck, panang curry, seafood soup, and pad Thai. The portions will satisfy a very hungry person or else provide leftovers. The waitress was nice and available just the right amount.

I live near the restaurant so have been there several times over the past few years.  My two recent dinners there were disappointing.   The eggplant salad was a plate of cold, undercooked strips of eggplant with a red spicy but tasteless sauce plunked down on it,  not marinated or stirred up or anything.  It was terrible. Some of the other dishes are too spicy, sour or salty.  Just no subtlety.  You can get better food at a truck.

Cute date night spot.. the pumpkin soup was AMAZING.  I'm a pumpkin lover, so this definitely raised the bar for the Silk Elephant from me. Vegetarian friendly.  You'll see me back here soon, must have another bowl of that soup :)
Great location, but not the best place in Pittsburgh for Thai food.  However, it was still pretty good.

I've come here so many times - it's a Pittsburgh favorite for me and my best friend. This quickly became a place where we celebrated birthdays, galentines day, no exams etc. 

I love all the food here - I typically got appetizers or one of the curries. My favorites were the seafood dumplings, wild curry, noodle curry, and panang curry. 

The ambiance is really great and it felt like a fancy restaurant without the exorbitant cost that typically comes with restaurants that have the feel that Silk Elephant does. 

I would highly recommend this restaurant and I actually like it better than Nicky's Thai Kitchen.

Interestingly, you can find quiet good Thai food in Pittsburgh which is unusual for a city that is not a diverse community by any means.

I have tried Silk elephant ,Thai Place, Smiling Banana Leaf, and Bangkok Balcony. They all were good but Silk Elephant is my favorite so far.

My first experience with this place was a take out on a snowy night. I just craved Thai food and Yelped ( of course ! ) and came across Silk Elephant. I ordered Mixed vegetables with beef and that was it. Since then Silk Elephant is my to go Thai Place.

Dishes that I have tried:

Pad Thai : I order this with beef. very delicious. one of the best Pad Thai's I have had. generous portion.

Mixed vegetables : again I order it with beef , and rice. It comes with a delicious brown sauce and is one of my favorites. generous portion.

Red Curry : Perfect blend of flavors. regular portion. 

They also have pretty good spring rolls.

Overall, service is great, food is quite decent, and price is pretty reasonable. Give it a shot if you are craving Thai!

My girlfirend loves thai food.  Acutally she loves hawaii fried rice.  So she is constantly wanting to get Asian.  We finally tried Silk Elephant last month and all I can say is wow!  Out of all the asian restaurants we have eaten at, this is one of the best.  The basil fried rice is great.  The tapas were tasty and come in decent portions.  One thing about all the food I have tried - it all have tons of flavor!  

One little quirk, the silverware.  Its heavy rounded steel that makes it a bit difficult to use at times.  But that is no reason to not try the food.

We came here for my birthday dinner and you can neverrrr go wrong with Thai food. Silk Elephant was bumpin' so good thing we made reservations. The lighting was a little dim but not bad, our service was quick but we didn't feel rushed and the cocktails were perfectly mixed. All the vegetarian apps were fried and that was slightly annoying and i forget the name of the one curry we had, "wild" something?, was terrible. We will for sure be back because the rest of the good was great.

Oh Silk Elephant, I must apologize--I had pre-judged you, and was quite mistaken in my impression.  You see, I'm a die-hard SBL fan, and when my favorite Thai curries prepared to my spice specifications are available for such a low price, why would I ever go to a pricy imitator?  I came in quite reluctantly while trying (and failing) to avoid a lovely Pittsburgh downpour, but I was quite surprised at what I found.
Silk Elephant carves out some new territory, blending the array of Thai curries offered by SBL and others with pan-Asian small plates.  I opted for the grilled lamb and some dumplings, and the lamb was AMAZING.  Best lamb I've ever eaten.  I wish there had been more...but I guess small plates are small!

Service was also quite nice, with a passing busboy taking pity on our drowned-rat-selves and sending a flurry of cloth napkins our way. Waters were refilled promptly and the lamb was actually a recommendation from the server. Cheapskate that I tend to be, I probably will continue to frequent SBL for my simple Thai cravings, but I'll be back for that lamb.

Been here twice, once with a large group in the evening and once on a Sunday mid-day with my husband.  Both experiences were very good and I was satisfied with my orders.

For the dining experience with the group, I ordered a couple of small dishes which were flavorful.  For the Sunday meal, I ordered pineapple fried rice which came with a small salad and spring roll as well as soup, a pleasant addition to the meal for under 9.00.  Can't beat that.

It's only a short walk from here to the Manor theater.  You can elect to park on the street with metered parking or there is a nice garage at Forbes and Murray Ave that is convenient, as well.

I probably can't say it any better than Julian did (check out his review), but the tapas at this place is awesome. We ordered the haw mork fish, and everybody loved it so much that we had to order more.

The main curry dishes are just average though. This place really shines as a tapas place, and that's what I'd recommend anybody to get there -- forget any of the main dishes because you can just go to Bangkok Balcony just around the corner.

Service is actually pretty awesome and the staff is very friendly and knowledgeable of their dishes.

I have to edit this because I just ate there tonight and had a not-so-pleasant experience. The restaurant was empty, it being a weeknight and all, but it still took us forever to get our food. We ordered soup and then several minutes later the waiter came back to take the rest of our order - the food we ordered later came before our soup. Not cool. We ordered a beef curry and I lost my appetite in response to the fact that the beef was not tender at all, in fact almost crunchy in a way. This was a very uncomfortable experience... the hostess even seated us at a small cramped table instead of a more spacious booth despite the fact that it was empty. We were one of out of three parties in the entire restaurant. I think I won't be going back here anytime soon.

Not to mention that the party next to us seemed like obnoxious working adults having a mid-life crisis in need of a trendy and exotic foray and proving their capacity to be interesting and exciting by eating thai food, trying to act like some sort of thai savant by ordering a 'thai beer' that was actually chinese. Yeah. 
_________________________________________________________

Old Review:

The Thai food here is definitely Americanized and not as spicy as it should be, but I'm always more satisfied with a place that automatically brings out the spice dishes so that you can instantly add more spice to your plate - also helpful when sharing dishes / ordering for groups. The decor definitely looks nice, although sometimes I question whether certain aspects are actually 'thai'... nonetheless, friendly service, I've never had any bad experiences, and if you are a student in the Oakland area, this is probably the best choice for thai food...

I like this place, quite a bit. I have been two or three times now and it's always been empty inside (didn't seem to matter the time of day) so service has been super prompt and friendly. We've tried the basil fried rice, red and green curries, and a bunch of their appetizers. The apps weren't really of either of our liking for the most part. They seemed rather bland, which made me a little nervous before I had gotten to try the main course, but every thing was delicious after that. Their red curry is dynamite, but, as mentioned in other reviews, their shiz is hot! I've taken it down to a 5/10 and it was still causing my eyes to water. They have f*cked up view of what's spicy and what's mild, but the curry was still super delicious.

One of the top 3 Thai Places in Pittsburgh definitely. Ambience gets 5 stars! However even though the food is GREAT! Its not completely authentic tasting. The Pad Ki Mao with Shrimp was excellent so was the Fried Rice. Helpings are small (per person) so sharing one entree is not an option. I will be back definately.

I split four orders of tapas with a friend. The first dish I tried was fish cakes. The cakes were a bit bland with the scallions in the cakes being the most prominent flavor; I couldn't discern the type of fish from the taste of the cake, but the fish cakes came with a tasty ginger sauce (which was called a cucumber sauce). 

Next, I tried chicken wrapped in a panandus leaves. It was a hassle to uncover the chicken because you are not supposed to eat the leaves, but it ended up being my favorite tapa. The chicken had an unique spice to it but was also a little dry; the dish did come with a sesame sauce which made the dish less dry (but was likely some soy and corn syrup based sauce).

The third dish I tried was Thai shrimp and pork toast with a layer of sesame seeds on top. I thought this was the most interesting tapa; however, my palate must not be sensitive enough to discern the subtle flavors because I did not taste any shrimp or pork with the breading and the sesame seeds contributing all of the flavor.

Last, I tried a mixed seafood dumpling. It was probably my second favorite tapa, but the serving was quite tiny and the dough was too thick for such a small dumpling. If the dumpling had more filling then this could have been a very good dish.

The service was fine. Our waitress was knowledgeable about the specials and was quite nice. The entire staff was also friendly.

As a student at CMU, Silk has been one of my go-to spots for large groups and satisfying my Thai food cravings. 

The Thai food gets the job done at a good price; however I'd say it isn't the best I've had in Pittsburgh. They have a great lunch special and generous portion sizes. Wished they gave me more shrimp with my curry fried rice though. Only had 4 pieces on a mountain of rice. I normally never order fried rice dishes, but this one was pretty flavorful! I'd recommend that here. 

My point of concern: I recently had dinner there. We ordered around 8 PM and the food didn't come out until after 9 PM. Frankly, I was disappointed & hungry. I was also surprised that they couldn't split the check 8 ways. I've definitely been there before with a large group, and they were able to do so...

Recently ate at Silk Elephant and immediately thought, why haven't I been coming here more often? Everything about my meal was top-notch. Started with the Fresh Rolls, comes two per order, stuffed with fresh tofu, rice noodles, carrots, lettuce, mint, basil, etc., served with a sweet brown sauce topped with peanuts. Delicious, huge, and oh so fresh! They were chock-full of incredibly fresh ingredients, and even the sweet sauce and the fresh peanuts added so much additional flavor. Light app but also so filling. For my entrée I got the Pad See Ew with vegetables, made vegan by omitting the egg and fish sauce. It was truly out of this world. One of the best Pad See Ew's I've ever eaten - the flavor was bursting, the noodles were so broad and fresh, 8/10 spice level was perfectly spicy but not too overwhelming, and it was loaded with so many veggies. Not one thing I would have changed. Asked for some extra chili sauce on the side which I only had to use with the spring rolls, as my noodles were perfectly seasoned. Cannot wait to come back and try some additional entrees.

I like their food, well done and always tastes good. I have had only one issue in 3 years of ordering from here--provided an incorrect dish.

Otherwise, great ambience, nice food, and decent waiting staff--the older staff is a bit rude (or in other words lack good service experience).

Im a HUGE fan of Silk!  The food is always delish. You can't go wrong with their Crispy Duck Salad, Moo and Goong Steamed Dumplings, Pad See Ew, Pumpkin Curry ( which is served all year round, not just in the fall). The list goes on and on...everything is good.  

The bar is the best in Squirrel Hill, not exaggerating.  It is the perfect place to have a cocktail and Sean, the best bartender I know, really knows his stuff.  He can make any and everything!  My personal favorite is his Lemon Drop Martini...it's to die for (check out the picture).  They have an excellent wine selection too.  

In a nutshell: The decor is great, the food is great, the drinks are great! Great way to show off Squirrel Hill to guests.  GREATNESS!
LOVE it. Great food, great selections. Extremely friendly staff. Definitely recommend it! Can be a bit pricey if you are real hungry.

The food took forever to arrive, it was cold upon arrival. They thought for some reason it was OK to service us without forks, napkins or any utensils for that matter. We called them back to bring us some forks as we work in an office without any. They took 3 hours and 4 phone calls later. No remorse. 
We called to explain the situation and they claim they do not deliver forks with any meal unless specificcally requested. Bs. We order once a week they always bring food. No more service from us. They lost us.

I have taken a few dates here, usually they are pretty good about taking reservations. However, they tend to have someone pick up the phone who barely speaks english, which is a bit of a hassle.

The place is fun, vibrant, chill atmosphere. It is on the expensive side. I have not had a single one of their tapas that I thought were so good, that you should order them. I do like one of their soups, the one with basil and is a bit spicy. Other than that, I can't recommned a single thing. 

Oh and both dates were crappy... and I rock on dates, so I know it was Silk Elephant that screwed me over, and then screwed me over again by charging me so much for such mediocre food.

Probably the best Thai place in Squirrel Hill, which has a number of really nice Thai eateries. The tapas here are quite unique and extremely mouthwatering. A few of my personal favorites include the salmon dumplings, corn fritters, Thai crab crowns, siam paragon and pork and shrimp toast. The curries are standard Thai curries and their Panang curry is especially nice. The fruity fried rice is another favorite for which I keep coming back here. The taste in most of these dishes has been quite consistent over the years. The service is always good 

Last time we ordered thai pork and shrimp toast, Tom yum soup along with the fruity fried rice. All three were very good as expected. Also had the Thai Iced Tea which was refreshing. No reasons for anything less than a 5 star.

Don't order delivery on a Friday night, still waiting for my food an hour and 30 mins later! Starved. And it's only jut now on its way. Worst of all I ordered through grub hub and already tipped 20% which I now wish I could take back. So much for a nice Friday night in. I couldn't wait any longer so have eaten now and no longer need the food. I know Friday's are crazy but still, almost 2 hours is ridiculous

The presentation was impeccable, the service was top-notch, and the decor makes for a decent date location. I'm not sure if I'd categorize this as "tapas" though...most of their tapas list seemed like straightforward appetizers to me.

The food was pretty good too, but the spice was definitely turned down and everything was slightly sweetened for some reason.

Given the choice of so many quality Thai places in the area, I'd say that Silk Elephant is probably one of front runners. It's a bustling little restaurant, but the service is fast, the staff is friendly, and the food is delicious.  They offer a very affordable lunch menu that will suit anybody's tastes.

I've never had a bad meal, every visit has been worth the tab and more. The rack of lamb makes you want to dance! It's tender, full of flavor and it's juicy to the core. The pumpkin soup is hearty, smooth-creamy, spices are on point, warms you from the inside out. The Thai spring rolls with plum sauce is a great start to your meal. 

In addition to wonderful food, the presentation is great, and their staff - very attentive to your needs. Great place for a romantic date night.

Pretty Delish Dishes. More Thai fusion in flavor not authentic thai flavors. Thai inspirted perhaps is a better way to put it. Nice environment pretty Decor and spacious room for my elbows :) A girlfriend and I went early on a saturday afternoon so we were seated right away there is also a bar you can sit at. 

We chose to share 3 tapas dishes and split a fried rice

Salmon rolls perfect texture with the crispy outside fried and salmon puree inside also very complimentary spicey sauce with a nice tanginess to it. 

Crab fried wonton with cream cheese also melt in your mouth good but very tiny you get 4 for 4.50 they are a little larger than a large gumball you probably should get at least 5 or 6 for the price but oh well. 

Corn Cakes were just ok they are a little over sweet with the sauce served peanuts added are yummy though. I would try something else. 

Curry fried rice I thought it was supposed to be yellow curry but it wasnt really you can taste some tumeric but it was a little dry other than that. It was full of  yummy veggies and spicy as we had asked for though they use red pepper flakes not fresh peppers in it. Overall it was flavorful a little on the sweet side.

Bill was $32 for one thai iced tea one plate of fried rice and three tapas all in all a decent price for a lunch date. I'll be back to try more tapas!

Silk Elephant is one of my favorite places in Pittsburgh. The atmosphere is cozy and romantic, but the big glass windows allows you to people-watch Murray Ave. It's a great combo!

Their food is to die for. I'm usually a Green Curry, spice 7 with shrimp. I was in the mood for something different and ordered the basil fried rice. I highly recommend it! The abundant fresh basil was bursting, and the rice was not greasy at all. 

As for their tapas... I haven't had any I don't rave about. Their corn fritters are some of the best I've ever had. Each tapas comes with a unique dipping sauce that makes eating the bite size meals that much more enjoyable.
Great service, nice decor, amazing chicken spring rolls and very reasonable pricing!!

It was Friday night and Kay's turn to choose a restaurant. She spun the wheel, the pointer landed on Squirrel Hill's Silk Elephant, and Eastward we headed after work. 

Never before have I been impressed with silverware. Silverware!  I suppose I take it for granted, but at Silk Elephant, I marveled at it.  Here our knives, forks, and spoons were seemingly forged by mythical blacksmiths, resembling swords, spades, and tridents. Their handles were thick, cylindrical and were looped at the end. It was as if combat was imminent. 

We ordered two tapas; Salmon Rolls and the Seafood Steamed Dumplings. The Salmon Rolls came with what seemed to be a remoulade and therefore happily reminded me of my mothers salmon cakes. The Seafood Steamed Rolls are comprised of crab and shrimp and come with a ginger sesame soy sauce. Both were heavy, moist, meaty, each pleasurable parcel sticking to my insides like pierogi from a world away do. We could have easily eaten a devil's dozen of each. Our appetites had been sufficiently stoked.

I ordered the Duck Curry since duck is something I don't have often, and did the roasted, boneless, supple, fatty duck ever deliquesce delectably in my mouth along with chunks of tomato, grape, and pineapple. The broth of coconut milk and curry astonished my tongue with its delicate sweet/spicy highwire waltz. I poured it onto my white rice and relished its exotic flavors. When I ran out of rice, I asked for more and dumped it all into the bowl without regard for rules. 

Kay ordered something really interesting that I had no idea existed that Silk Elephant calls Fruity Fried Rice. It the usual fried rice but with an obvious twist, the fruits added consisting of pineapple, apple, grapes, raisins, and oranges. Enormous twin cucumber discs acted as a garnish. Kay added shrimp to give it some more ooomph. Upon having a taste I couldn't get over how savory it was and how well the fruit went with the rice. 

My few forays into the world of Thai cuisine have been interesting, Silk Elephant only adding more depth to that memoir. One thing I have taken away from my experiences with it so far is that Thai food is so remote yet close to home at the same time. Each time I've had Thai food, I've recalled something I've had before. As I mentioned earlier, the rolls reminded me of my  Irish/German/Hungarian mother's cooking and the dumplings of Poland, but in the case of the Duck Curry, I felt as if I had been whisked away to India and Thailand and back home again. In spite of the trendiness of the restaurant and the neighborhood it sits in, I felt comfort. I felt as if I had at least something in common with people I've never met and whose language I don't speak. It may sound shallow, and I'm clearly not alone in thinking this, but I've always been of the opinion that food can connect people to cultures, even if only by a thread. The Silk Elephant did so for me with an affectionate, ebullient, and mighty trumpet call. Praise be to the Taffeta Pachyderm.

I LOVE Silk Elephant! The food is delicious, and the service is outstanding! I am an event planner with Meetup.com. I'm the main organizer for a group called Pittsburgh Dining N' At, and an assistant organizer for ten other Meetup groups. When I plan a dinner, I often cross-post the event on multiple Meetup groups, resulting in quite a few RSVPS. I have now been to Silk Elephant with a large group of people TWICE in 2013 on major holidays, and both times they did an outstanding job of accommodating our needs.

My group went there for dinner on Easter Sunday and Christmas Day 2013. Both times, the food was fantastic and the service was excellent. I asked for separate checks, which is not easy in a group of 18 people for Easter, and 12 people for Christmas dinner. The event planner and the wait staff went out of their way to help make these two dinners a huge success. Everyone had a great time and raved about their food. I look forward to going back again soon, since everything on the menu looks so good. I took a lot of pics of the food, so you can see for yourself the delicious food we enjoyed. I highly recommend Silk Elephant.

I wish I could give it 4 and a half stars instead of just 4. But anyway.

This place has been around for a while now. I am surprised it was able to stay in business (considering how many other businesses have gone under on the same street.)

The food is really, really good. It's Thai but also sort of Malaysian or something. I am not 100% on that. But it's definitely Thai and maybe something else. There is a lot of seafood used in their dishes and same with fruit and spicy flavors. Whoever came up with a lot of the appetizers really knows how to blend flavors together, harmoniously.

To drink I always order either mango juice, Thai Iced Tea, or hot floral tea. 
To eat, my favorite dish is the Siam Paragon. This is also my mom's favorite. (And I would like to point out that she does not even LIKE Thai food and she loves to eat here!) Their coconut rice is TO DIE FOR. It's SO tasty and sweet, almost like a dessert. I've also tried Haw Moork Fish, Salmon Rolls, Spring Rolls, and the Spicy Siam Mussels on the half shell. I am sure I've tried a few other of their tapas too but it's been a while so the names aren't coming to me as I type this. But basically, it's all really good. A lot of dishes have some spiciness to them so if you don't like spicy foods then you might wanna steer clear or play it safe and order something not so spicy like spring rolls or pad Thai. 
I've had their Red Curry with chicken and their chicken Pad Thai. Both are really tasty. The mildest level for the red curry is still a little bit spicy, though. 

The tapas are the best, though, and if you are undecided, try the Siam Paragon and the Spring Rolls with chicken (or veggies if you prefer.) Those are both tried & true dishes. 

I've never really tried their alcoholic drinks so I can't comment on those, or the desserts.

I REALLY love their interior too. Easily one of the most "romantic" interiors in town, or at least in the Sq Hill area. The lighting, decor, and the waterfall by the door....all very nice for a night out!

Regarding the prices--pretty affordable if you order 3-4 appetizers and split among you and one other person or more. My mom and I spent about $35 total for the both of us including a tip for our meal, and we were pretty filled...two mango juices, coconut rice side order, siam paragon, mussels on the half shell, spring rolls, and salmon rolls.

The only reason why the Silk Elephant did not get 5/5 stars is due to the service. It can be really really REALLY slow in there sometimes, even when there aren't many other people eating there. Once you place your order, it seems to speed up a bit, though.
my coworker recommends it and we tried it. The food is good but it is on the pricy side. Don't think we will try it again.

Silk Elephant has good food. We enjoyed our meals, and the atmosphere is nice: somewhat upscale with a Thai influence but still comfortable. The service was very attentive.

However, for Thai in the East End, you can get better food at better prices.

First off, please ignore any of the reviews that give this place a hard time for not being traditional Thai food. When you see that they have a tapas menu, among other unique items on the menu, it should be evident that the concept of Thai is only a starting point here. 

My husband and I went on a Saturday night for dinner. We had a reservation for 6:30 but it seems the restaurant doesn't get busy until around 7:30. Even though they have an extensive wine list, we brought our own bottle (corkage fee is $15). We had six different small plates - each one of them fresh, hot, and served with a delicious sauce.

Our waitress, Ilene, was fantastic. She was very attentive and had great timing for the pace of our meal. It turns out that she is the owner! We also complimented the managed, who was very friendly as well. 

Overall, we got exactly what we came for: a relaxing, slow, savory, tapas meal in a casual, intimate restaurant.

We went to Silk Elephant after partaking in a movie.

Ordered the Mussels and discovered it came with 2 mussels and all filler.  I requested a second order without the filler.  Literally, a single bowl of 2 mussels came out.  

For the prices, portions (even considering it's tapas) are pathetic.

Honestly you can never go wrong at this place the food is catered to you weather it be the ingredients or the service. With out a doubt on my top 5 let alone my top 3. This place is where you wanna go trust me. If you can't decide on a meal pick some appetizers or tapas quick n simple portions of amazing food that will give you a feel of what you want.

One of the best lunch deals in the city!
Comes with soup, salad, spring roll, plus entree. Love it here.

Been here a few times in the past, and enjoyed the spice and noodle dishes, but recently came back and was disappointed by the slow service, despite the fact the restaurant was empty, and the waitress who was rude. Will not be coming back here again.

Boring, not authentic.  Food was quite spicy on a 3/10 scale but HOT peppers alone to not make an authentic, correctly-spiced Thai meal.

Very pretty decor, though.  I would go there again, for a business lunch

I don't have a lot of money to explore Pittsburgh's many restaurants right now.  I'm really bummed I wasted an opportunity on this one.

I went here for my 1-yr wedding anniversary this past weekend and really liked it. My husband got the duck curry and I got the pad thai with beef. Our waiter was really soft-spoken and nice. We gave him a big tip because he was great. Our portions were a good size, the taste was great and the ambiance is very upscale. The prices were regular (between $13 - $18 for an entree). 
The seating is very tight and I felt like they were really making people squeeze into their narrow booths and chairs. The customers on either side of me kept brushing up against me and dropping my coat. I would come back but only in warmer weather on a week night to avoid the density of people.

One of the best thai restaurants in the Burgh. Authentic recipes. Esp recommend the tom yum soup and drunken noodles. Lunch specials are great value as you get a bean soup, salad and egg roll with entree for $8.50. Service was great and decor was nice!

Me and my wife went for a dinner here today. Order didn't showed up for half an hour. And the food quantity not justified for the price at all. 

Most insane stuff - I gave a tip of 10% considering all the suffering, stepped out of the restaurant and the waitress ran out and caught us for more tip. She acted like they were so great and amazing that they require minimum 15% tip. I hate that attitude. Very bad experience. 

Not recommended at all!
This is the best Thai food I've ever had! Completely adore the tapas style of ordering, and I always get the mussamun curry.

This is a great place, in a fun, funky neighborhood. The decor was more sophisticated/upscale but the prices weren't. I thought the food was great, and they stuck to their spiciness scale religiously. A 5 on a scale of 10 was perfect for me. I had the classic Pad Thai and Spring rolls. They were very yummy! The service was also good - polite and attentive. I would recommend it to anyone.
Came for the Sunday brunch buffet.  Most of the food was cold. Suggestions: use sternos under all of the pans and cover them. Other than that, the selection was very good.

This is a good spot that I  just happened to stumble upon on a Sunday  afternoon because of an open parking spot.  It's located in Squirrel Hillwhere "Zyng asian grille" used to be.  This is a much better choice than the TGIF of asian food like Zyng.  The atmosphere is colorful and warm.  The ceilings are high and the seating is plentiful.  I sat at the bar, which has a nice plasma and a better than average wine selection.  The menu is big and I think thai food is a good choice to be served tapas style.  I ordered a glass of chardonnay to start which tasted fine and wasn't too overpriced, however the bartender poured what must have been only a 3 oz. pour.  The wine comes in cocktail glasses, so perhaps it was an optical illusion that I misinterpreted.  Nevertheless, I mentioned it before I ordered another glass and was given your customary 6 oz.  I started with a delicious pork and seafood dumpling, which was really tasty and almost as good as Nicky's thai in Verona.  Next I tried the chili pepper scallops, which were cooked perfectly, but lacked much spice for what was advertised as a spicy dish.  In addition, I'd have preferred one or two big scallops instead of four little scallops.  Last I tried the calamari, which were served with an interesting guacomole sauce, however the calamari and breading were flavorless and not delicate at all.  They looked like onion rings, but weren't as good.  The prices are okay, but this is definitely on the higher end of thai food costs.  Overall, good place with an interesting concept that I'll visit again.

Up in Squirrel Hill, there are two Thai restaurants: Bangkok Balcony and its younger more 'hip' sister restaurant, Silk Elephant. Thai places aren't usually on my restaurant rotation so usually I end only end up visiting them for special occasions (birthdays, etc.). But one fateful day, the Groupon of the day was 30 bucks for $60 at Silk Elephant. I realized it's been a while since I've returned, so I decided to make a return trip.

In case you're not familiar with how Groupon works, you basically get to buy a gift certificate to a restaurant or service for half the face value (sometimes less!). My friend and I underestimated the cost of dishes at Silk Elephant (too many visits to Tamari makes you forget not every tapas place in the world costs an arm and leg) and ended up proceeding to order 4 tapas in addition to main entrees and drinks to get to the $60 mark (I'm missing some pics b/c we were too busy nom-ing on food and getting tipsy; our drinks ended up bringing us well over $60, oops haha). No, we didn't finish everything, and during the entire meal various other tables kept looking over at the masses of food that appeared on our table.

Anyways, overall the food is generally good; I want to say their curries and noodle dishes are almost identical to Bangkok Balcony (which would make sense being sister restaurants). If you choose to go the tapas route (which I personally wouldn't recommend unless you're sharing with a companion so you can also get or split an entree), I'd have to say their lamb rack is my favorite altogether: cooked well (happens rarely, but sometimes a little bit overcooked, but I'm extremely picky), nice sauce pairing and just a large enough portion for you to savor it without it being overwhelming or filling you up. I'm not too fond of the rolls, but everyone else I know seems to like them.

With main entrees, the curries and noodle dishes are what you would expect; I like my curries to have a bit more spice and dimension to them, but my palate is probably different from your average diner. If you're a spicehead, you probably know what I mean when I say it's difficult to get dishes as hot as you want... =/

Overall I'd say 3.5 stars for the food, but I'll round up because the ambiance is nice, service is always excellent, and they have a decent bar.

I think I love this place because it has all the elements that make a great dining experience...super cozy intimate ambiance, solid wine list, and really tasty food! This is probably my favorite Thai place in Pgh to go to. The tapas I usually order as an appetizer because they are kind of small...but still really tasty. When my husband and I go, we usually end up getting an actual dish versus just going there for true tapas. Our faves are the red and panang curry, the red curry noodles, and the curry chicken rice. All in all pretty affordable for the quality of food you are getting. Also, if you want spicy...just tell them...I have found that the curries are spicier on their number scale in comparison to a rice dish...so just keep that in mind. Enjoy!

I don't know how I missed this place all these years. I was here with my friends for dinner. It was a great experience and I could not thank my friend more for introducing me to silk elephant flavors. 

We ordered corn fritters, basil fried rice, red curry and Kee Mao. It was appropriate quantity of food for four people and the prices are in a reasonable range. 

Corn fritters looked like a simple yet tasty dish. That was a very good start to our main course. I will give basil fried rice the highest rating followed by Kee Mao and the red curry. Basil fried rice is not too spicy and not too bland. It is a plate of rice filled with amazing flavors. Kee Mao tasted as good as the one I had at other popular Thai place is Pittsburgh. It is big flat tasty  rice noodles. Red curry is like any typical curry that you would find in a Thai restaurant. It has coconut flavour along with other curry spices. 

I will definitely go back and I added this to my list of hearty meal restaurants that I can frequently visit.

I may have discovered a great date spot! Let's talk wine: decent selection, would like to see more btg options since they do call themselves a wine bar. The silk elephant rice paper rolls: I died and went to fresh flavor heaven. Get them I swear you'll be happy! Asparagus soup: super crazy temperature hot- worth the wait of the cooling down process! Ok main course: so good I got the pad se kow. Yum yum yum! Staff is friendly and hold a good conversation without being in your business. I highly recommend silk elephant!
